>

> Do we even test methods that do not do anything, other than call parent ,
> and the parent also does not do anything.

So you want to test that Subclass.activateOptions() behaves exactly the
same way as Superclass.activateOptions()?

Here is how I would do it.

1. Write tests for Superclass.activateOptions(), as normal.

2. Move those tests into their own class called
SuperclassActiveOptionsTest.

3. Everywhere in the tests you create an instance of Superclass, extract
to a method called create().

4. Introduce a new abstract test case class to be the superclass of
SuperclassActivateOptionsTest, called ActivateOptionsContractTestTemplate.

5. Declare the method create() abstract in
ActivateOptionsContractTestTemplate.

6. Move all the tests up into ActivateOptionsContractTestTemplate.

Now SuperclassActivateOptionsTest inherits all the tests from
ActivateOptionsContractTestTemplate.

7. Create a new class SubclassActivateOptionsTest extends
ActivateOptionsContractTestTemplate.

8. Implement create() to return a Subclass instead of a Superclass.

Now SubclassActivateOptionsTest inherits /the same tests/ from its
superclass as SuperclassActiveOptionsTest. You will run the same tests
against each implementation.

NOTE: If you are using Eclipse 2.x or earlier, the test runner does not
correctly run tests when a class declares /no/ tests of its own (but
inherits them all from above). In this case, add a testDummy(){} to each
of your implementation test classes.

That should do it.
